Agenda detail: Thematic discussion on trafficking in human beings, especially women and children
cosponsored countries: Germany, Greece, Italy, Netherlands and Sweden
body title detail: The Commission on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice recommends to
body text: the Economic and Social Council the approval of the following resolution for adoption by the General Assembly: Promoting and strengthening assistance to victims of trafficking, especially women and children The General Assembly, Recalling the Declaration of Basic Principles of Justice for Victims of Crime and Abuse of Power! and also the Guide for Policy Makers on the Implementation of the United Nations Declaration of Basic Principles of Justice for Victims of Crime and Abuse of Power and the Handbook on Justice for Victims on the use and application of the Declaration of Basic Principles of Justice for Victims of Crime and Abuse of Power, Recalling also the Convention on the Rights of the Child? and the Optional Protocol thereto on the sale of children, child prostitution and child pornography,3 Recalling further the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime* and the Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, Especially Women and Children, supplementing the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime,> 3 Resolution 54/263, annex II. 4 Resolution 55/25, annex 1. Recalling the Vienna Declaration on Crime and Justice: Meeting the Challenges of the Twenty-first Century, © and especially paragraphs 25 and 27 thereof, which refer to support of victims of crime, including mechanisms for mediation and restorative justice, upholding victims’ rights, witness protection and establishment of funds for victims, and the plans of action for implementation of the Vienna Declaration,” Recalling also International Labour Organization Convention 182 of 1999, concerning the Prohibition and Immediate Action for the Elimination of the Worst Forms of Child Labour, which prohibits forced or obligatory labour of all people under the age of eighteen, Recalling further Economic and Social Council resolutions 2002/14 of 24 July 2002, on promoting effective measures to deal with the issues of missing children and sexual abuse or exploitation of children, and 2002/16, also of 24 July 2002, on international cooperation in the prevention, combating and elimination of kidnapping and in providing assistance for the victims, Profoundly alarmed by the fact that trafficking in persons is a growing and profitable trade in most parts of the world, aggravated by poverty and inadequate social and economic conditions, Reaffirming its deep concern at the various forms of trafficking in persons, especially women and children, who are especially vulnerable and thus often victimized, Convinced that civil society can play a role in reducing existing and future opportunities for victimization by traffickers and in assisting Governments in promoting protective elements through comprehensive and non-stigmatizing social and economic assistance to victims, including in the areas of health, education, housing and employment, 1. Vigorously condemns and rejects all forms of trafficking in persons; 2. Urges all Member States to collaborate in developing and implementing measures to discourage the demand that fosters all forms of exploitation of persons, especially women and children, that leads to trafficking, pursuant to the provisions of article 9, paragraph 5, of the Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, Especially Women and Children, supplementing the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime;° 3. Urges Member States that have not already done so to adopt the legislative or other measures necessary to establish a wide range of assistance, including legal, psychological and social assistance, to all victims of trafficking, provided that the existence of victimization has been determined; 4. Invites Member States to draw up and adopt minimum standards for the protection of the victims of trafficking before, during and after criminal proceedings; 5. Urges all Member States to ensure that all existing measures against trafficking in persons, especially women and children, are consistent with 6 Resolution 55/59, annex. 7 Resolution 56/261, annex. E/CN.15/2003/L.10 internationally recognized principles of non-discrimination and that they provide for respect for the human rights and fundamental freedoms of victims; 6. Urges Member States to inform victims of trafficking about the services or organizations to which they can turn for support, their role in reporting to the police and appearing in court as witnesses and their right to compensation and to safe repatriation; 7. Exhorts Member States to raise awareness among criminal justice officials of the special needs of victims of trafficking, by means of programmes and initiatives that would ensure, inter alia: (a) As regards the police, investigation of all cases reported by victims, prevention of further victimization and in general treatment of victims with respect; (b) As regards the judiciary, sensitive treatment of victims called to testify in court as witnesses and provision of an opportunity for child witnesses and vulnerable adult victims to testify, when necessary for the protection of the victim, in a manner that avoids open court proceedings, direct contact between victims and offenders and invasion of the privacy of victims and of their families; (c) As regards criminal proceedings, involvement of victims by assigning to them an appropriate role, that is, to be heard, to provide evidence and to be offered, where appropriate, the services of an interpreter and legal assistance free of charge; (d) As regards probation or similar services, addressing the needs of victims in a comprehensive and coordinated manner and avoidance of partial or inconsistent solutions that may result in secondary victimization; 8. Encourages Member States to set up mechanisms for coordination and collaboration between governmental and non-governmental organizations that will provide for the emotional and practical needs of victims of trafficking; 9. Urges Member States to create awareness among civil society concerning the seriousness of the crime of trafficking and of its various forms, as well as the responsibility of citizens in preventing victimization and in assisting victims of trafficking; 10. Invites Member States to strengthen mechanisms to identify and locate kidnappers, and to combat conditions that foster slavery and trafficking in persons of all ages, in particular for the purposes of sexual exploitation and pornography; 11. Urges Member States to develop and improve international cooperation, especially mutual legal assistance and collaboration between law enforcement authorities, through exchange of information with a view to providing effective protection of the interests of victims of trafficking in persons; 12. Invites Member States to establish or improve training programmes for judges, prosecutors, law enforcement personnel and especially officials working in cross-border activities and health practitioners, who come into contact with victims of trafficking in persons and are responsible for preventing this form of victimization and for providing multifaceted assistance to victims of it; E/CN.15/2003/L.10 13. Invites the Centre for International Crime Prevention of the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime?® of the Secretariat, in cooperation with other relevant international and regional organizations, to assist States in the development of relevant legislation and regulations and to provide other expertise or technical assistance for the ratification and implementation of the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime’ and its Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, Especially Women and Children, and encourages Member States to continue to support the work of the Centre in this area by making voluntary contributions to the United Nations Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice Fund for this purpose. 8 Formerly known as the Office for Drug Control and Crime Prevention.
